title: Event co-ordinator
change: Occupational standard, end-point assessment plan and funding band revised but funding remained the same.
overviewOfRole: Working in an events company or events department in an organisation, helping event planners and project managers to organise and host events.
occupationalSummary: <p>An Event Co-ordinator is an entry level position, typically working within a team of people in an events company or within the events department of a larger organisation. The role would usually provide support to a number of Event Planners or Project Managers by carrying out a diverse range of tasks necessary to plan, organise and deliver an event: for example, searching for the right location and venue for the event; working with the design team on the look and feel of the event; or organising logistics like transportation and catering. The events organised may be for the company where the Event Co-ordinator is working, or could be for a variety of different clients including large corporations, smaller companies and not- for-profit organisations. Events cover a broad range of activities as well as sizes, from small numbers of attendees through to thousands. Around 75% of events are conferences, meetings, trade shows and exhibitions. Other events include outdoor events, cultural events, sporting and music events. Companies use events to bring together different groups of people: from employees attending a sales conference; to customers or suppliers attending the launch of a new product; to shareholders gathering at a conference designed to attract new investors. These are just a few examples – the breadth and diversity of the events industry is partly what makes it such an exciting place to work. As well as holding events in the UK, events agencies and events departments organise events in different countries around the world.</p>

knowledges.detail: The lifecycle of an event from research and planning to delivery and evaluation.
The roles and responsibilities of logistics, production, creative and design in event management and how they impact and contribute to the delivery of an event.
Methods and approaches for identifying different venues suited to events based on their requirements including online.
The impact that logistics have on the delivery of an event, for example venue, attendees, transport, accommodation and catering, and suppliers.
The responsibilities of the event delivery team to meet both event and attendees’ requirements.
Regulation, legislation and policies and the impact of these on the event co-ordinator’s role and organisation.
Principles and practices of stakeholder management.
Methods and approaches for assessing an event’s purpose, goals, budget and resource requirements.
Methods and approaches for evaluating events and work processes for example stakeholder feedback and impact analysis.
Principles and practices of data and information collection, research and analysis.
Methods, principles and the tools used for time management and prioritisation.
Organisational priorities and processes and the role, responsibilities and accountability of event co-ordinators in relation to these.
The different types of events.
Principles and practices to ensure commercial awareness, including budget management, expenditure, and forecasting.
Digital tools, processes and trends and how they support and impact on business activities.
Methods and approaches to assess and mitigate risk for example health and safety.
Techniques and approaches for negotiating and influencing stakeholders and reducing conflict.
Methods and tools for the identification and solution of others’ learning needs.
Communication techniques and approaches to build relationships with stakeholders and meet their requirements.
Principles of equity, diversity and inclusion and their impact on attendees, the organisation and the team.
Practices and processes to ensure sustainable and ethical event management.
Project and change management tools and techniques, including monitoring.
Methods and media for communicating and presenting information to meet the needs of different audiences.
The impact that internal and external factors  have on events and the event co-ordinator’s role.
Coaching and continuous professional development techniques.

behaviours.detail: Acts professionally, ethically and with integrity.
Takes accountability and ownership of their workload and the accuracy of their tasks
Seeks learning opportunities and continuous professional development.
Works flexibly and adapts to circumstances.

skills.detail: Research, analyse, collate, and present information in response to a brief or request.
Communicate information through different media, such as face-to-face meetings, emails, reports, and presentations to enable key stakeholders to understand what is required.
Interpret and respond to requests from stakeholders to assist in the planning, delivery, and evaluation of an event.
Deliver onsite or online support for events and attendees.
Prioritise tasks according to their importance and urgency.
Use technology and dedicated software to produce documentation, for example spreadsheets and presentation packages to communicate information.
Contribute to reports and event documentation.
Identify current and future challenges and trends in technology that impact on event management and delivery.
Interpret and apply regulation and legislation, and advise stakeholders on their application.
Collaborate with the stakeholders of an event so those stakeholders can contribute throughout the planning and organisation processes.
Question stakeholders to understand event requirements.
Develop and maintain relationships with stakeholders.
Negotiate with and challenge stakeholders in order to make decisions and manage change.
Work within a group to prepare, deliver and follow up after an event takes place.
Support the preparation, management, and reconciliation of event budgets by collecting information, checking data, and making calculations.
Manage time and prioritise tasks to deliver within budget and resource requirements.
Interpret the event brief and the responsibilities of the event co-ordinator to meet these.
Review work processes to identify learning opportunities for the team and individuals.
Support the development of the team through informal coaching and continuous professional development.
Support equity, diversity and inclusion in the workplace and at an event.
Monitor the use of technology and the potential to reduce energy consumption through their optimisation in managing an event, for example an online event.
Apply sustainability goals and requirements, share best practices, and advise stakeholders on their application.

eQAProvider.contactAddress:
Ofqual
Earlsdon Park, 53-55 Butts Road, Coventry, CV1 3BH

involvedEmployers: Abstract Events, Bright Vision Events, Broadsword, DRP Group, ETP, IMG, NEC Group, Royal Opera House, Sheffield Hallam University, Stress Matters, We Are Massive
englishAndMathsQualifications: <p>English and maths qualifications must be completed in line with the <a rel="noopener" href="https://www.gov.uk/guidance/apprenticeship-funding-rules" target="_blank">apprenticeship funding rules</a>.</p>
reviewDetails: this apprenticeship will be reviewed in accordance with our change request policy.
clusterDescription: Plan, organise and deliver key marketing actions and events

duties.dutyDetail: Collaborate with the project or account lead to understand an event brief and agree roles and responsibilities.
Use IT and software to manage the project documentation and monitor actions against the event plan.
Plan and prioritise tasks to complete the event within agreed timescales.
Research, identify and contact internal and external resources to collate and present event information to stakeholders.
Contribute to the design and implementation of the sustainable and ethical practices of an event.
Support stakeholders to ensure the application of equity, diversity, and inclusion principles.
Monitor and apply operational policies, relevant legislation, and regulation, and makes recommendations to ensure stakeholder compliance.
Identify, asses, and monitor potential risks, and supports the mitigation of risk within the event planning environment.
Support the event lifecycle through administrative tasks such as sending resources to site and attendees, responding to enquiries, marketing, taking payments and registrations.
Collaborate and build relationships with stakeholders to meet event expectations and objectives.
Contribute to the content creation or programming relevant to event objectives.
Support and deliver the onsite event and breakdown to meet the event design and requirements.
Contribute to the evaluation of the event.
Contribute to the training and development needs of the individual or the team.
